_metadata.description: Training manifesto based on van der Poel, Norwegian triathlon method, applied to 5K track running with bike-based volume
primary_sources: Nils van der Poel - How to Skate a 10k (2022)
Norwegian Triathlon Federation - Blummenfelt/Iden training methodology
Lionel Sanders - High volume self-coached approach

core_philosophy.summary: Massive aerobic volume builds the engine. Specificity comes later. Recovery is training. Fuel the work.
van_der_poel_axioms: The way to improve is to train more, recover more, and sleep more
Volume is the foundation; intensity is the sharpening
Threshold work is the primary intensity - it's specific and sustainable
Recovery between sessions matters more than the sessions themselves
Periodization: build volume blocks, then add intensity, then taper
Consistency over heroics - sustainable load trumps peak sessions
norwegian_method_principles: High total volume (20-35 hrs/week for elites, scaled for context)
Threshold zones (lactate 2-4 mmol/L) are the primary intensity
Double days distribute load and improve recovery capacity
Lactate-guided pacing - stay in zone, don't chase pace
High carbohydrate availability for all quality sessions

athlete_situation.constraint: Returning from femoral neck stress fracture
athlete_situation.strategy: Build aerobic base via cycling while running returns gradually

why_this_works.van_der_poel_parallel: Van der Poel used massive volume of skating-specific and cross-training to build aerobic capacity for 10K skating. The aerobic system is the limiter in 5K running (85-90% aerobic). Bike volume builds the same central aerobic adaptations without bone loading.
transfer_mechanism: Central cardiovascular adaptations (stroke volume, cardiac output)
Mitochondrial density in type I fibers
why_this_works.implication: Bike builds the engine; running specificity sharpens the application. Phase 1 is engine building.

current_phase.name: Phase 1: Bike Base
key_sessions: Tempo blocks within easy rides (15-30 min at tempo)
Double days when volume target requires

next_phase.name: Phase 2: Run Reintroduction

intensity_distribution.running: Mostly easy with progressive tempo introduction
intensity_distribution.cycling: Easy volume, reduce as running increases

key_milestones: Week 5-8: Build to 20 mpw, introduce strides

race_phase.name: Race Sharpening
key_sessions: Race-pace intervals (1K-mile repeats at 5K goal pace)
race_phase.taper: Final 7-10 days reduce volume 40-50%, maintain intensity

easy_ride.intensity: Conversational, HR 60-70% max, can talk in sentences
easy_ride.fueling: Fuel based on duration - see fueling rules

tempo_ride.intensity: Comfortably hard, HR 70-80% max, can speak in short phrases
tempo_ride.duration: 30-90 min of tempo within longer ride

threshold_intervals.structure: 2x20 min, 3x15 min, or 4x10 min with equal rest

long_ride.intensity: Mostly easy with optional tempo blocks
long_ride.purpose: Volume accumulation, fat oxidation, mental endurance
long_ride.fueling: Critical - 60-90g/hr carbs, do not ride fasted

tempo_run.intensity: Comfortably hard, roughly half-marathon to 10K effort

intervals.note: Only in final 6-8 weeks before goal race

fueling_philosophy.core_principle: Fuel the work. High carb availability for all quality sessions. Never train low when training hard.

easy_session_under_90min.requirement: Optional, can do with light meal or fasted if truly easy

easy_session_over_90min.timing: 2-3 hours before: full meal (carbs + protein + fat)
easy_session_over_90min.alternative: 1 hour before: simple carbs (oats, banana, drink mix)

quality_session.timing: 2-3 hours before: carb-focused meal, low fat
quality_session.rationale: High carb availability improves quality and adaptation

under_60min.carbs: Optional, water sufficient if well-fueled before

over_90min.note: Train the gut - practice race fueling in training

high_intensity.rationale: Intensity burns glycogen faster, needs constant supply

norwegian_approach.principle: High carb availability for threshold and above
norwegian_approach.detail: Norwegian athletes typically consume 8-12g carbs/kg/day on high training days
norwegian_approach.scaled_for_context: At 165 lbs (75kg), target 600-900g carbs on big volume days, ~400-500g on moderate days

sleep.van_der_poel_quote: Sleep is when adaptation happens. Train more = sleep more.

between_sessions.double_days: Minimum 4-6 hours between sessions, ideally eat and nap between
between_sessions.day_to_day: If HRV is below baseline for 3+ days, reduce volume

mandatory_deload_if: Persistent fatigue not resolved by one rest day
deload_triggers.deload_protocol: Reduce volume by 30-50% for 3-5 days, maintain some movement

rules: No fasted long sessions (cortisol + low energy availability = bone risk)
Maintain calorie intake - deficit should be modest (400 kcal max)
Calcium and vitamin D intake per nutrition goals
Any hip/groin discomfort = stop and reassess

volume_progression.van_der_poel_principle: Add volume in blocks, not linearly. Absorb the load, then add more.

weekly_structure.pattern: Build -> Build -> Absorb -> Build -> Build -> Absorb

volume_increase_rate.cycling: Add 2-3 hours per week during build weeks, cap at manageable load
volume_increase_rate.running_when_added: Add no more than 10% per week, prefer 5%

volume_caps.phase_1_cycling: 20 hours/week max (constrained by life, not physiology)
volume_caps.phase_2_total: Running + cycling should not exceed recovery capacity

polarized_vs_threshold.van_der_poel: Heavy threshold focus - it's specific to 10K skating
polarized_vs_threshold.norwegian: Mix of easy + threshold, very little VO2max until race phase
polarized_vs_threshold.for_5K_running: 5K is ~85% aerobic, so threshold and easy volume dominate. VO2max work only in final 6-8 weeks.

should_i_do_intensity_today.if_unsure: Default to easy volume - you can always add intensity, you can't undo overtraining

yes_if: Sleep has been poor multiple nights
no_if: Just feeling lazy but metrics are fine
Slight tiredness that easy movement would help
should_i_take_a_rest_day.alternative: Easy spin or walk instead of full rest if unsure

how_long_should_today_ride_be.principle: Distribute volume to protect key sessions. Long rides should not compromise next day's quality.

van_der_poel_mindset: Trust the process - fitness comes from consistency, not heroics
Easy days should feel easy - ego has no place in zone 1
Hard days should be hard - but sustainable and purposeful
Recovery is training - rest without guilt
Long term > short term - one bad session means nothing
during_hard_sessions: If form breaks down, end the interval

phase_1_success.body_composition: Weight stable or slowly decreasing per plan

phase_2_success.fitness_transfer: Easy runs feel easier than expected given time off
phase_2_success.threshold: Can hold tempo paces at reasonable HR

race_success.process_goal: Execute race plan regardless of time
